It is necessarily a dup of itself ;-)
Anyway I think this bug belongs to platform / core.
*** Bug 68152 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Is this related to the problem discussed a while ago where the resources plug-in
is doing too much in its startup method?

yes.  it would be interesting to know if the workspace is really big or 
complicated etc. Typically loading the workspace will not be that slow.

Not really. It's 287 classes (counting the generated .class files, so inner 
classes etc. included) and it I give it 300MB of memory on the cmd. line. I am 
using AspectJ which slows down some things but not really badly.

This was also reported as bug 60566. From the viewpoint of the resources plugin,
this message is unfortunate but will not cause any problems.  I tried to make it
less likely by forcing the autorefresh thread to sleep on first execution, but
clearly it did not wait long enough. 

I believe this will only occur either after a crash, or when -refresh is used.
The only long work that is done during resources plugin startup after the
autorefresh job starts is the global refresh that runs in one of those two
situations. If this refresh (and any resulting resource listeners) take a long
time, the message will be logged.
*** Bug 74973 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 75167 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 75279 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 78755 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
I also found this in my log.
I'm seeing this on every startup with the last couple of builds.

I'm seeing this as well, except the class being loaded is different than those
previously reported:

While loading class
"org.eclipse.jdt.internal.corext.util.AllTypesCache$1$RequestorAbort", thread
"main" timed out waiting (5000ms) for thread "Worker-0" to finish starting
bundle "org.eclipse.jdt.ui". To avoid deadlock, thread "main" is proceeding but
"org.eclipse.jdt.internal.corext.util.AllTypesCache$1$RequestorAbort" may not be
fully initialized.

Not sure if this is relevent, but, only when I started switching workspaces (and
two of my three workspaces are large) did this problem start happening - which
now happens regularly.  It also happens when I startup with my very small,
single project workspace as well.

Shoot - forgot my particulars... running on WinXP, JDK 1.4.2, Eclipse 3.1M4.  I
have three workspaces - one contains all projects found in jboss-4.0 sourceforge
CVS module, another contains all projects found in jboss-head sourceforge CVS
module, and a third contains a very small, one project workspace.  Some plugins
of note that I have installed: JBoss IDE 1.4, JBoss AOP, XmlBuddy, jadClipse,
Jalopy.

John M, in your case it is happening with a different component. I suggest
entering a bug against JDT UI for that one.
see bug #81766 - written up against JDT UI.

Fixed.  I now force the background refresh job to wait until the resources
bundle is no longer in the "STARTING" state before proceeding.
